title-group.article-title: DETERMINANTS OF GROSS NATIONAL SAVING IN MALAYSIA: A MACROECONOMIC ANALYSIS 1960-2000

abstract.p: This paper extends the empirical knowledge on the determinants of gross saving ratio in Malaysia utilizing the Johansen-Juselius (1990) cointegration and error-correction model to deal with the nonstationarity properties of time series of the variables involved. The advantage of this statistical approach is that it avoids the problem of spurious regressions. The results suggest that saving ratio is determined by dependency ratio, economic growth, interest rate and foreign direct investment (FDI) in the long run. The short-run error-correction model reveals that in addition to these five variables, saving ratio is also influence by tax policies and growth in exports. The major findings of this study can be summarized as follows: (a) economic growth appear to play a key role in explaining the high saving ratios observed in the past three decades, (b) dependency ratio leads saving ratio â€” a result in line with the lifecycle theory, (c) foreign capital inflows, as measured by FDI, adversely affect saving ratio but its impact is only temporary, (d) interest rate carry a positive (negative) sign in the long- (short-) run saving ratio and hence supporting the McKinnon-Shaw hypothesis in the long run, and (e) the effect of tax and trade expansion policies on domestic saving is positive but it is only temporary.
